poem:
"From a Desk in Indiana"

A web of complaints, not a lean, keen tool,
but a misguided trap, a spiteful pool.
Teachers cry out - "Good intention's fool!"
The ink of indignation, their sword and tool.
Whispers in classrooms turn loud and cruel,
Parents and teachers, both played for the fool.
In the end, it's the student who pays the school.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Indiana teachers say website for parents’ complaints ‘creating a bogeyman’ An alliance of Indiana teacher unions has called for the removal of a website encouraging parents to report teaching material they perceive as indoctrination, saying it is dividing parents and teachers. The state attorney general Todd Rokita launched the Eyes on Education portal earlier this month, prompting criticism from educators for hosting outdated and inaccurate information. Educators in Indiana shared their concerns with the Guardian". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
